title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: interest fostering open welcoming environment, contributors maintainers pledge making participation project community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, disability, ethnicity, gender identity expression, level experience, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes creating positive environment include: Using welcoming inclusive language respectful differing viewpoints experiences Gracefully accepting constructive criticism Focusing best community Showing empathy towards community members Examples unacceptable behavior participants include: use sexualized language imagery unwelcome sexual attention advances Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical electronic address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Project maintainers responsible clarifying standards acceptable behavior expected take appropriate fair corrective action response instances unacceptable behavior. Project maintainers right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, ban temporarily permanently contributor behaviors deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within project spaces public spaces individual representing project community. Examples representing project community include using official project e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event. Representation project may defined clarified project maintainers.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported contacting project team .pearse@usu.edu. project team review investigate complaints, respond way deems appropriate circumstances. project team obligated maintain confidentiality regard reporter incident. details specific enforcement policies may posted separately. Project maintainers follow enforce Code Conduct good faith may face temporary permanent repercussions determined members project’s leadership.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 1.4, available https://contributor-covenant.org/version/1/4

title: Overview
text: Thank interest contributing suppdata! important contribution can make suppdata add code download data another publisher’s journals. five steps go ; go detail , briefly, : Write download function publisher Modify DOI lookup function knows download function Modify documentation suppdata user knows ’ve done Write brief unit test checking function works Submit pull request want make small change suppdata (.e., changing <= 5 lines code) fork repo, make change, make pull request suggestion. want make sweeping change (.e., > 5 lines code) writing code make issue discuss @willpearse. purpose make maximal use everyone’s time: small code changes better “just done” can talk ; larger changes require discussion implementation. ’re quite welcome whatever wish code (within boundaries license, course), please aware maintainers package obligate accept pull requests. course, ROpenSci maintainer rules apply, ’ll always polite ’ll always let know make decision! :D making version changes, please follow standards set CRAN, next version “1.2-9” “1.2-10”. Package versions numbers decimal, something like “1.2.9.5” won’t pass CRAN’s checks (see R extension guide)

what: (1) Write a download function for a publisher
title: Overview
text: suppdata download functions start , minimum, something like: …nameofpublisher replaced name publisher ’re loading data . followed something like: Note name section (#Argument handling), ’re making sure user gives us supplement number need , using .character ’re expecting character SI info. internal functions make life easier (…well, …); .tmp.dir make temporary directory save files , .save.name generate sensible name save files well. ’s quite important use functions, since make cache behaviour package work. Next comes hard work, get data publisher’s website. lot regular expression kung-foo; may find functions .grep.url, .grep.text, .url.redir, functions utils.R useful. Please poke around , feel free add functions think missing (using .name.function. convention non-user-facing functions). ’s something think useful , don’t know write , just make issue, tag (@willpearse), ’ll see can . Finally, need return user location file want. Something like: …suffice. Notice ’re using R’s file.path make sensible path distributions, ’re using internal .download download file, guaranteeing ’ll obey cache instructions etc. ’re also ensuring user get sensible filename information (“oooh, looks like .csv file”) attribute using .download. Save function journals.R. plenty examples get stuck. also list functions written sitting issues section GitHub. ‘hit list’ publishers great write wrappers issues page - click link see .
code: .suppdata.nameofpublisher <- function(doi, si, save.name=NA, dir=NA, cache=TRUE, ...) #Argument handling if(!is.numeric(si))     stop("nameofpublisher download requires numeric SI info") dir <- .tmpdir(dir) save.name <- .save.name(doi, save.name, si) destination <- file.path(dir, save.name) return(.download(url, dir, save.name, cache))

what: (2) Modify the DOI lookup function so it knows about your download function
title: Overview
text: ’re nearly now, promise! suppdata uses rcrossref look articles’ publishers, hook download function package ’re going figure journal’s code. Take paper’s DOI know works, run following (replacing DOI DOI ’re checking): …number publisher’s code. Modify first switch statement suppdata.func utils.R add journal’s number (character string) match name download function. sounds complicated, open function become obvious. Next, modify second (last) switch function work publisher known name. match onto function’s name. , example, publishing company called Pearse Publishing, ’d called function .suppdata.pearse, add entry like: Please remember case statements separated commas; add comma previous entry keep code syntactically correct!

title: Overview
text: Modify roxygen documentation give user information function expects (numeric vs. character SI information). Re-build documentation ’re done running something like: …’re RStudio person ’s button “Build” tab (“” > “Document”). ’re emacs person like , several probably strong opinion best :p

what: A more detailed set of motivations for suppdata
title: Downloading Supplementary Data from Published Manuscripts
text: suppdata R package provide easy, reproducible access supplemental materials within R. Thus suppdata facilitates open, reproducible research workflows: scientists re-analyzing published datasets can work easily stored computer, others can track analysis workflow painlessly. example, imagine conducting analysis evolution body mass mammals. Without suppdata, analysis require manually downloading body mass phylogenetic data published manuscripts. time-consuming, difficult (impossible) make truly reproducible without re-distributing data, hard follow. suppdata, analysis straightforward, reproducible, sources data clear DOIs embedded within code:
code: # Load phylogenetics packages library(ape) library(caper) library(phytools)  # Load suppdata library(suppdata)  # Load two published datasets tree <- read.nexus(suppdata("10.1111/j.1461-0248.2009.01307.x", 1))[[1]] traits <- read.delim(suppdata("E090-184", "PanTHERIA_1-0_WR05_Aug2008.txt", "esa_archives"))  # Merge datasets traits <- with(traits, data.frame(body.mass = log10(X5.1_AdultBodyMass_g), species=gsub(" ","_",MSW05_Binomial))) c.data <- comparative.data(tree, traits, species)  # Calculate phylogenetic signal phylosig(c.data$phy, c.data$data$body.mass)

title: Downloading Supplementary Data from Published Manuscripts
text: aim suppdata make easy possible write reproducible analysis scripts make use published data. let’s start first, simplest case: make use published data analysis.

title: Downloading Supplementary Data from Published Manuscripts
text: example analysis run using suppdata. Read first, ’ll go parts mean. short script loads R packages focused modelling evolution species’ traits, gets “good stuff”: using suppdata. First, load suppdata package using library(suppdata). next line uses function called read.nexus, loads something called phylogeny (might familiar ’re biologist). Normally, function take location file hard-drive single argument, now ’re giving output call suppdata function. suppdata going website article whose DOI 10.1111/j.1461-0248.2009.01307.x (’s paper Fritz et al.), taking first (1) supplement article. saves temporary location hard-drive, gives location read.nexus. works function expects file location hard-drive. particularly neat suppdata remembers downloaded file already (see details), download something per R session. second call suppdata, makes use read.delim, shows two potential complexities suppdata. First , journal publishers store supplementary materials using numbers others using specific file-names, suppdata takes either number (like first example), name (like second example) depending journal publisher ’re taking data . look help file suppdata, table outlining options. Sorry, ’ve just got read :-( Secondly, ’re ecologist might familiar Ecological Society America’s data archives section. ’ve moved new way storing data recently, ’re hoping load older dataset journal need give ESA data archive reference specify ’re downloading ESA (example). ’re ecologist, don’t worry , doesn’t apply :D ’s ! now know need order use suppdata! rest lines code merge datasets together, calculate something called phylogenetic signal datasets. ’re evolutionary biologist, lines might interesting . ’re , don’t worry .
code: # Load phylogenetics packages library(ape) library(caper) library(phytools)  ############################### # LOAD TWO PUBLISHED DATASETS # #       USING SUPPDATA        # ############################### library(suppdata) tree <- read.nexus(suppdata("10.1111/j.1461-0248.2009.01307.x", 1))[[1]] traits <- read.delim(suppdata("E090-184", "PanTHERIA_1-0_WR05_Aug2008.txt", "esa_archives"))  # Merge datasets traits <- with(traits, data.frame(body.mass = log10(X5.1_AdultBodyMass_g), species=gsub(" ","_",MSW05_Binomial))) c.data <- comparative.data(tree, traits, species)  # Calculate phylogenetic signal phylosig(c.data$phy, c.data$data$body.mass)

title: Summary
text: suppdata R [@R2018] package provide easy, reproducible access supplemental materials within R. Thus suppdata facilitates open, reproducible research workflows: scientists re-analyzing published datasets can work easily stored computer, others can track analysis workflow painlessly. example, imagine conducting analysis evolution body mass mammals. Without suppdata, analysis require manually downloading body mass phylogenetic data published manuscripts. time-consuming, difficult (impossible) make truly reproducible without re-distributing data, hard follow. suppdata, analysis straightforward, reproducible, sources data [@Fritz2009, @Jones2009] clear DOIs embedded within code: example makes use code packages ape [@Paradis2004], caper [@Orme2013], phytools [@Revell2012]. suppdata , originally, part fulltext [@Chamberlain2018], already used number research projects. One project natdb, package builds database functional traits published sources. software currently available GitHub (https://github.com/ropensci/suppdata), plan distribute ROpenSci CRAN.
code: # Load phylogenetics packages library(ape) library(caper) library(phytools)  # Load suppdata library(suppdata)  # Load two published datasets tree <- read.nexus(suppdata("10.1111/j.1461-0248.2009.01307.x", 1))[[1]] traits <- read.delim(suppdata(         "E090-184", "PanTHERIA_1-0_WR05_Aug2008.txt",         "esa_archives"))  # Merge datasets traits <- with(traits, data.frame(body.mass = log10(X5.1_AdultBodyMass_g),                        species=gsub(" ","_",MSW05_Binomial))) c.data <- comparative.data(tree, traits, species)  # Calculate phylogenetic signal phylosig(c.data$phy, c.data$data$body.mass)

title: Download supplementary materials from journals — suppdata
code: suppdata(   x,   si,   from = c("auto", "plos", "wiley", "science", "proceedings", "figshare",     "esa_data_archives", "esa_archives", "biorxiv", "epmc", "peerj", "copernicus",     "jstatsoft"),   save.name = NA,   dir = NA,   cache = TRUE,   vol = NA,   issue = NA,   list = FALSE,   timeout = 10,   zip = FALSE )  # S3 method for character suppdata(   x,   si,   from = c("auto", "plos", "wiley", "science", "proceedings", "figshare",     "esa_data_archives", "esa_archives", "biorxiv", "epmc", "peerj", "copernicus",     "jstatsoft"),   save.name = NA,   dir = NA,   cache = TRUE,   vol = NA,   issue = NA,   list = FALSE,   timeout = 10,   zip = FALSE )

title: Download supplementary materials from journals — suppdata
text: x One : vector DOI(s) article(s) (character) ESA-specific article code. si number supplementary information (SI) downloaded (1, 2, 3, etc.), (ESA, Science, Copernicus journals) name supplement (e.g., "S1_data.csv"). Can character numeric. Publisher article (character). default (auto) uses crossref (cr_works) detect journal's publisher. Specifying journal can somewhat speed download, used force download EPMC (see details). *must* specify downloading ESA journal (esa_data_archives, esa_archives). can use argument x vector DOI(s). Must one : auto (.e., auto-detect journal; default), plos, wiley, science, proceedings, figshare, esa_data_archives, esa_archives, biorxiv, epmc, peerj, copernicus, (Data)dryad), mdpi, jstatsoft. save.name name file download (character). NA (default) combination DOI SI number dir directory save file (character). NA (default) temporary directory created files cache TRUE (default), file downloaded already exists (temporary directory creates, chosen dir) vol Article volume (Proceedings journals ; numeric) issue Article issue (Proceedings journals ; numeric) list TRUE, print files within zip-file downloaded EPMC (default: FALSE). ** useful using EPMC (see details) timeout long wait successful download (default 10 seconds) zip TRUE, force download binary format order ensure zipped files work Windows (default FALSE).

title: Download supplementary materials from journals — suppdata
text: examples probably give best indication use function. general, just specify DOI article want download data , number supplement want download (1, 5, etc.). Proceedings, Science journals need give filename supplement download. file extensions (suffixes) files returned suffix attributes (see first example), may useful know format file downloading. DOIs recognised (asked) European PubMed Central API used look articles. database calls supplementary file varies publisher; often simply figures within articles, (obviously) way check run-time. strongly recommend run EPMC calls list=TRUE first time, see filenames EPMC gives supplements, also often vary authors gave . may actually 'feature', 'bug', trying automate sort meta-analysis. list publishers supports, examples journals . auto Default. Use cross-ref search (cr_works) DOI determine publisher. plos Public Library Science journals (e.g., PLoS One;) wiley Wiley journals (e.g., Ecology Letters) science Science magazine (e.g., Science Advances) proceedings Royal Society London journals (e.g., Proceedings Royal Society London B). Requires vol issue article. figshare Figshare biorxiv Load bioRxiv epmc Look article Europe PubMed Central, download file using supplementary materials API. See comments 'notes' EPMC. peerj PeerJ journals (e.g., PeerJ Preprints). copernicus Copernicus Publications journals (e.g., Biogeosciences). one supplemental supported, can zip archive PDF file.  numeric si parameter must 1 download  whole archive, saved using Copernicus naming scheme (<journalname>-<volume>-<firstpage>-<year>-supplement.zip) save.name ignored, download PDF. si matches name supplemental archive (.e. uses Copernicus naming scheme), suppdata archive unzipped. si may name file  archive, file extracted saved save.name.

title: Download supplementary materials from journals — suppdata
text: Pearse (.pearse@usu.edu) Scott     Chamberlain (myrmecocystus@gmail.com)

title: Download supplementary materials from journals — suppdata
code: # NOTE: The examples below are flagged as 'dontrun' to avoid # running downloads repeatedly on CRAN servers if (FALSE) { #Put the function wherever you would put a file path crabs <- read.csv(suppdata("10.6084/m9.figshare.979288", 2))  epmc.fig <- suppdata("10.1371/journal.pone.0126524",                        "pone.0126524.s002.jpg", "epmc") #...note this 'SI' is not actually an SI, but rather an image from the paper.  #View the suffix (file extension) of downloaded files # - note that not all files are uploaded/stored with useful file extensions! attr(epmc.fig, "suffix")  copernicus.csv <- suppdata("10.5194/bg-14-1739-2017",                            "Table S1 v2 UFK FOR_PUBLICATION.csv",                            save.name = "data.csv") #...note this 'SI' is not an SI but the name of a file in the supplementary information archive. } # (examples not run on CRAN to avoid downloading files repeatedly)
